awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Hybrid Socio-Technical Teams: A Theoretical Framework for Modeling and Design of Hybrid Networks of Human and Autonomous Agents
awd_abstract_narration:
Many critical systems in the future will rely on coordinated teamwork of a hybrid group of humans and smart, decision-making, autonomous agents. Such hybrid teams are becoming increasingly common in a wide variety of socio-technical systems. Members of such teams are highly heterogeneous, work in rapidly changing and uncertain environments, have different goals and motivations, and are often spatially distributed with little direct face-to-face interaction. This creates serious challenges for team-level coordination and cooperation, and can result in decreased efficiency, or even disastrous failure, in some critical cases. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed understanding of dynamics, behavior, and coordination mechanisms of human-agent networks. Outcomes of this project will result in better understanding of the behavior of such networks, and more efficient design of future intelligent systems for disaster response, energy and transportation, all of which will in the future rely on efficient, dynamic coordination between a group of people and a network of autonomous agents. 

Understanding hybrid teams and addressing their coordination challenges require an interdisciplinary approach that combines computational and behavioral sciences. To this end, this research will combine multi-agent computational methods such as complex network analysis and game theory with social psychology of team behavior. The research team will create parametric, context-dependent, analytical and computational models to understand how team-level coordination and cooperative behavior are affected by variables such as composition of team members, communication network structure among nodes, distribution of humans and machines on networks nodes, and key parameters in the environment. Analytical methods, such as game theory on graphs, and verifiable agent-based simulations will be used to draw causal inferences from the network structure and agent compositions to overall team-level performance parameters. The research will also test the hypothesis that the connectivity structure of the team network can be used as an effective control parameter to dynamically steer the cooperative behavior of hybrid socio-technical systems. To validate the developed models, the research team will perform a data-driven study of disaster response teams.  It will investigate the impact on overall coordination and efficiency when introducing autonomous agents into human disaster-response teams.

por.por_cntn:
Many critical systems in the future will rely on coordinated teamwork of a hybrid group of humans and smart, decision-making, autonomous agents. Such hybrid teams are becoming increasingly common in a wide variety of socio-technical systems. Members of such teams are highly heterogeneous, work in rapidly changing and uncertain environments, have different goals and motivations, and are often spatially distributed with little direct face-to-face interaction. This creates serious challenges for team-level coordination and cooperation, and can result in decreased efficiency, or even disastrous failure, in some critical cases. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed understanding of dynamics, behavior, and coordination mechanisms of human-agent networks. Outcomes of this project result in better understanding of the behavior of such networks, and more efficient design of future intelligent systems for human-robot design activities, disaster response, energy and transportation, all of which will in the future rely on efficient, dynamic coordination between a group of people and a network of autonomous agents. 

To understand the driving forces of team behavior in hybrid networks, the research team employed an interdisciplinary approach that combines multi-agent computational methods such as complex network analysis and game theory with social psychology of team behavior. The research team created parametric, context-dependent, analytical and computational models to understand how team-level coordination and cooperative behavior are affected by variables such as composition of team members, communication network structure among nodes, distribution of humans and machines on networks nodes, and key parameters in the environment. Analytical methods, such as game theory on graphs, and verifiable agent-based simulations were be used to draw causal inferences from the network structure and agent compositions to overall team-level performance parameters.

As the first step, a set of parameterized models were developed for both human and autonomous agents:  Models created human agents can incorporate some behavioral factors important in the team psychology literature in a simple way that can be used in analytical and computational models. The research team  created two mechanisms in the agents that incorporate two important aspects of agents temporal attitudes, namely time urgency and time perspective. The team then incorporated some elements of agents bounded rational behavior in team interactions that can be attributed to random choices, in circumstances of low stake, high ambiguity, or cognitive overload. To capture the behavior of autonomous agents in a compact way,  our goal was to characterize three capacity constraints: i) Computational Capacity, Communication Capacity, and Learning Capability , using a compact set of parameters. The research team  then created a series of analytical and computational models to characterize the formation of various team-level behavior and the efficiency of team performance as a function of the connectivity structure among team members. The input to these models were based on the outcomes of the first objective. Three general models of teamwork were chosen depending on the problem structure and the trade-off between specificity and generalizability. Finally, to validate the models, the research team created a set of novel validation methods for agent-based simulation in heterogenous networks with strategic agents, and used the method to test some theoretical results of collective team behavior against empirical findings.
